2. Directly Clarifying the Present Realm, in Ten Parts: 1. Attachment to the Cause and the Caused, in Two Parts: 1. Based on Their Understanding

Ä€nanda, you should know that this good man has exhausted the emptiness of all activities, returned the consciousness to its origin, and already extinguished birth and cessation, but the subtle and wondrous essence of quiescent cessation is not yet complete.

Although the aggregate of formations has been exhausted, birth and cessation have already been extinguished, and consciousness has returned to follow the origin, it has not yet returned to quiescent cessation, so it is said that the subtle and wondrous essence is not yet complete.
Because consciousness has not yet been broken through, it is still in subtle birth and cessation.
Subtle and wondrous refers to the subtle and true wondrous illumination.

Able to cause one's own faculties to merge and open, and also to universally awaken with the myriad kinds in the ten directions. With the ability to universally awaken and merge, one can enter the fundamental source.
This is temporarily so in the contemplation.
Temporarily, in the contemplation, it seems to open the faculties, but it is not yet fully inter-dependently functioning.

Those who have realized the commonality of all things have already seen that the sentient beings of the ten directions and their own bodies have the same enlightened nature, mutually blending together without any distinction in awareness. This is precisely being able to enter the perfect source.
However, this realm is entirely the reflection of consciousness and is not yet quiescent and extinct.
Therefore, the previous text says, But in the subtle and wondrous essence of quiescence and extinction, they are not yet perfect.
If one takes the place of return as the cause of true permanence and gives rise to a superior understanding, is precisely giving rise to a conceptualization.

Taking the realm of common awareness that one has entered as true permanence, one establishes it as the cause that can give rise to everything, which is then the ultimate place of return, definitely without error. Therefore, it is called a superior understanding.
Second, determining that they belong to the category of the heterodox.

This person will fall into the conceptualization of the cause and the effect of the cause, becoming an ally of the Vaisnava followers who take the obscure principle as their ultimate return. They will be confused about the Buddha's enlightenment and lose the correct view.
This is called the first conceptualization of the attainment of the mind, which becomes the fruition of the ultimate return.
They go against the perfect penetration and turn their backs on the city of nirvana, giving rise to the seeds of non-Buddhist paths.
In the aggregate of consciousness, which is the basis, they grasp it as the true and eternal, the cause of myriad dharmas, thus it is called grasping the cause of causes.

The myriad dharmas have no cause, arising and ceasing in vain. Now, to calculate that there is a cause, which is the true and eternal nature, is no different from the eternal principle grasped by non-Buddhists, which is eternal and can give rise to everything. This is precisely taking the Älaya consciousness, before any signs appear, as the initial state of obscurity and making it the eternal principle.
As for being deluded about the Buddha's bodhi, bodhi means enlightenment, and the essence of enlightenment is free from thought.
The one free from the characteristics of thought is equal to the realm of space, pervading everywhere, with the dharma realm as its single characteristic.
Now, grasping that there are dharmas arising from a single cause, with distinctions between subject and object, is therefore called delusion.
Because one does not truly understand, it is said that one loses the insight of knowledge.
The mind one attains is precisely the aggregate of consciousness. In the cause, it is what is attained; in the fruit, it is what one returns to.
The remaining text can be understood.
Question:
In the following seven sections, it is said that what is able and what is unable, etc., but only this text is the cause of the cause?
Answer:

Because all dharmas arise from the transformation of consciousness, it is precisely the cause. Because of not understanding the falsity, it is grasped as truly the same, therefore it is the same as the non-Buddhist paths.
The following text directly reveals the falsity of the essence, therefore it says what is able and so on.
Second, the grasping of what is able and what is unable, in two parts:
First, based on what is grasped.
Ä€nanda!

Moreover, the good sons who have exhausted the emptiness of all activities have already extinguished arising and ceasing, but the subtle and wondrous essence of quiescent extinction is not yet complete.

If they regard what they return to as their own essence, and think that all sentient beings within the realms of space and the twelve categories are a single type that flows out from within their own bodies, and give rise to a decisive understanding, Although the previous grasping takes the consciousness aggregate as the cause of the eternal and unchanging, it has not yet been taken as one's own essence.
Now, I reckon that this is my own self. All sentient beings are born from me. I can give birth to them. This is definitely not a mistake.
Second, classifying it as a heretical group.

This person will fall into the attachment to the ability of non-ability. MaheÅ›vara manifests boundless bodies to be his companions. He is confused about Buddha's enlightenment and loses the view of knowledge.
This is called the second establishment of the able mind to accomplish the able matter fruit.
It goes against the perfect penetration, turns away from the city of nirvana, and gives birth to the great arrogant heaven, the seed of universal pervasion.
Truly not able to give birth, yet grasping it as able, is called the ability of non-ability.
MaheÅ›vara is the great self-existent god with three eyes and eight arms, the one who is revered by non-Buddhists as the able cause.
Manifesting boundless bodies means grasping that I can manifest innumerable sentient beings.
Since the cause is able, the fruit becomes able matter. Cause and effect correspond to each other.
Third, the attachment to permanence and impermanence, in two parts:
First, in terms of what they conceive.
Moreover, good men who have exhausted the emptiness of all activities, have already extinguished birth and cessation, but have not yet perfected the subtle and wondrous stillness.

If they take refuge in something to which they can return, they themselves doubt that their body and mind flow out from that, and that the ten directions of space arise from it. They then take the place where it is proclaimed and flows out as the eternally unchanging body, and have the understanding that it is without birth and cessation, while being in the midst of birth and cessation, they early on take it to be permanently abiding. Having been deluded and not giving rise to [understanding], they also misunderstand birth and cessation. Dwelling in and sinking in delusion, those who give rise to a superior understanding,... The place to which they return is the aggregate of consciousness. Previously they regarded the place to which they return as their own body, but now they take the place to which they return as the body of another, thus they doubt that their own body and all dharmas arise from it.
The place where it is proclaimed and flows out refers to the aggregate of consciousness.

They mistakenly take it to be true, eternal, and without birth and cessation. As for being deluded and not giving rise [to understanding], the eternally abiding original enlightenment does not give rise to all dharmas, but they are confused and do not understand.
Also deluded about arising and ceasing means mistakenly recognizing the aggregate of cognition as true and eternal.
Both are ignorant, hence it says deeply immersed.
Firmly grasping without turning back, hence it says dwelling in.
Second, judging them to belong to the category of the heterodox.
This person then falls into the attachment to permanence and impermanence, taking the god MaheÅ›vara as their companion, confused about Buddha's enlightenment, and losing the view of wisdom.
This is called the third kind of false conceptual result based on the mind that establishes causes.
It goes against the perfect penetration, turns one's back on the city of nirvana, and gives rise to the seeds of inverted perfection.
Attaching to permanence in the place of impermanence is called the attachment to permanence and impermanence.
The god MaheÅ›vara is the same as Åšiva.
Previously, they took others as arising from themselves; now they take themselves as arising from others, hence it says taking MaheÅ›vara as their companion.

The mind that establishes causes is the aggregate of cognition. Taking it as the body of others, they conceptualize it as able to give rise to themselves, hence it is the same as the non-Buddhists' conceptualization of it as permanent.
Fourth, the attachment to knowledge and ignorance, in two parts:
First, in terms of what they understand.
Moreover, good men who have exhausted the emptiness of all activities have already extinguished birth and cessation, but the subtle and wondrous stillness has not yet been perfected.

If they know that knowing is all-pervading and perfect, and therefore establish understanding based on knowing, thinking that the plants and trees of the ten directions are all sentient beings, no different from humans, and that plants and trees become humans, and humans after death become the plants and trees of the ten directions, without discrimination, they give rise to the superior understanding of all-pervading knowledge. The objects of knowledge refer to the aggregate of consciousness, because it is the object of their contemplation and practice.
The aggregate of consciousness can transform all dharmas, which is called knowing all-pervasiveness and perfection.
Realizing that all these dharmas arise from knowing and transform, and taking knowing as their essence, it is said that they establish understanding based on knowing.

As for the plants and trees of the ten directions, this is the aspect of practice in their understanding. Since the dependent and the primary are all due to knowing, how can there be one knowing and one without knowing?
Therefore, there is no discrimination.
All are known, and they consider themselves to be definitely correct, thus it is called superior understanding.
Second, it is classified as belonging to the heterodox.

This person then falls into the attachment to knowing what is unknowable, becoming companions with the attachments of all awareness of Bhrgu and Åšara, confusing Buddha-bodhi, and losing the view of knowledge.
This is called the fourth, taking the mind of complete knowledge to be false and erroneous results.
It goes against the perfect penetration, turns one's back on the city of nirvÄá¹‡a, and gives rise to the seeds of inverted knowledge.
Grasses and trees are without awareness, yet it is grasped as having awareness, thus it is said to be the attachment to knowing what is unknowable.
Bhrgu and Åšara are two non-Buddhists.
The NirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra says Bhrgu and Åšara, with a slight change in Sanskrit pronunciation. Since they grasp all awareness, it means grasses and trees have life.
Complete knowledge is all-encompassing knowledge.

As for false and erroneous results, it is criticized as being deluded thoughts. This is because one does not understand that they are all transformations of deluded consciousness, that deluded thoughts solidify to provisionally establish insentient beings, and that deluded thoughts flow to provisionally name sentient beings.
As the previous text says, When thoughts become clear, they form the world; when knowing and perception become clear, they form sentient beings.
Because of not skillfully distinguishing the false consciousness into inner and outer parts, one gives rise to attachment and speculation.
Fifth, the attachment to the non-arising of birth, with two parts:
First, discussing what they speculate about.
Moreover, good men who have exhausted the emptiness of all conditioned phenomena have already extinguished arising and ceasing, but the subtle and wondrous stillness has not yet been perfected.

If they have already attained accord in the interfusion of the faculties, they will then in all things that are transformed and interfused seek the radiance of fire, delight in the purity of water, love the circulation of wind, contemplate the accomplishment of dust, each revering and serving them, using these various phenomena to give rise to the fundamental cause, and establish the understanding of permanence. Those who have attained accord in the interfusion of the faculties have temporarily attained accord with the semblance samadhi, thus it says accord.
In all things that are transformed and interfused means that all phenomena are the same in being called transformations, thus it says transformed and interfused.
All can be cultivated and accomplished as the holy fruit, therefore it is said all arise.

By temporarily obtaining the various functions in one faculty, by this example one knows that all are also like this, all can cultivate and accomplish knowledge and vision in the midst of ignorance, and attain the abiding fruit, therefore seeking fire, enjoying water, loving wind, and contemplating dust.
Second, classifying them as belonging to the heterodox group.

This person then falls into the attachment to the birth of the unborn, becoming companions with the KÄÅ›yapa brothers and brÄhmans who diligently serve the body and worship fire and water, seeking to escape from birth and death and accomplish their companions, confused about the Buddha's enlightenment, losing the knowledge and vision.
This is called the fifth attachment to worship, confusing the mind and following external things, establishing false causes, seeking false fruits in vain.
Opposing the perfect penetration, turning one's back on the city of nirvÄá¹‡a, and giving rise to the seeds of inverted transformation.
The nature of the four great elements truly cannot give rise to the abiding fruit, yet grasping them as being able to give rise to it, therefore it is said attachment to the birth of the unborn.

Those who are confused about the mind and follow external objects lose the mind-only view and each follow and revere it to seek permanence. Cause and effect are both false, so it becomes a false seeking and false hope.
Sixth, the attachment to non-return, in two parts:
First, discussing what they understand.
Moreover, good men who have exhausted the emptiness of all activities have already extinguished birth and cessation, but the subtle and wonderful in quiescent extinction is not yet complete.

If in the perfect illumination they consider the emptiness within illumination to be not the cessation of myriad transformations, taking eternal cessation as the basis for reliance and give rise to conviction, the emptiness within illumination refers to the principle of perfect illumination, which is the consciousness that is observed.
Since birth and cessation have already been extinguished, it is therefore emptiness within illumination.
It is not the same as cessation, so it says not the cessation.
Form, feeling, perception, and mental formations encompass all dharmas, called myriad transformations.
Eternal cessation is precisely the emptiness within illumination.
This considers emptiness to be the place of reliance, which is nirvana.
Second, it is classified as a deviant teaching.

This person will fall into the view of non-return as return, becoming companions with the various Åšá¹›á¹…gaá¹­as in the Heaven of No Thought, confused about Buddha-bodhi, and losing the view of knowledge.
This is called the sixth fruition of emptiness and nothingness attained by the empty and false mind of emptiness,
going against the perfect penetration, turning one's back on the city of nirvÄá¹‡a, and being born in the type of annihilation.
This clarifies that the middle is empty and real, not a place to return to, yet it is considered a place to return to, thus it is called the view of non-return as return.

Seventh, the view of non-greed as greed, in two parts:
First, discussing what they consider.
Moreover, good men who have exhausted the emptiness of all activities, have already extinguished birth and cessation, but have not yet perfected the subtle and wondrous stillness.

If one is attached to the perfect and eternal, solidifying the body as eternally abiding, the same as the essence of the perfect and long-lasting, never declining, and gives rise to the understanding of victory, one grasps the aggregate of consciousness as perfect and eternal, and wishes to solidify this body to also be the same as the aggregate of consciousness. Therefore, it is said to be the same as the essence of the perfect and long-lasting, never declining.
Second, judging it to belong to the category of the heterodox.
This person will fall into the attachment of craving and non-craving, becoming companions with those who seek longevity, such as Asita, confusing Buddha-bodhi, and losing the view of knowledge.
This is called the seventh attachment to the source of life, establishing false causes for solidity and heading towards the effect of prolonged toil.
It goes against the perfect penetration, turns one's back on the city of nirvana, and gives rise to the species of false longevity.
The body of the sense faculties is illusory and originally impermanent, truly not to be craved for as long-lasting.
Now, firmly attached to craving, falsely grasping at longevity, therefore it is said to be the attachment of craving and non-craving.
Asita means incomparable, and refers to the immortal of long life.
The term long-lasting fruit is a mistake for firm fruit.
Delusionally grasping at prolonging life, hence it says deludedly prolonging.
8. Attachment to the real and unreal, in two parts:
First, discussing what they understand.
Moreover, good men who have exhausted the emptiness of all activities, have already extinguished birth and cessation, but have not yet perfected the subtle and wondrous stillness.

Observing that life interconnects, they hold back dust and afflictions, fearing their exhaustion, and then sit in a lotus palace at this juncture, extensively transforming the seven treasures, greatly increasing the precious maidens, indulging their minds, and giving rise to a superior understanding.  Observing the aggregate of consciousness as the source of life for sentient beings in the ten directions, it is the essential passageway for the lives of the twelve classes. Therefore, my life connects with theirs, and their lives connect with mine, hence it is said to be interconnected.

Now, if the aggregate of consciousness is observed to be exhausted, the lives of sentient beings in the ten directions will all be exhausted, and my life will also be exhausted. Exhaustion means teaching whom to realize the principle of eternal abiding?
Who will be the sentient beings to be transformed?

Merely having true permanence, without anyone realizing the truth, therefore retaining defilements, again giving rise to craving and desire, transforming lotus flower palaces and various sensual objects, wantonly enjoying sensual pleasures, plotting to prolong life without extinction, intending to realize the truth, give rise to function and transform beings. Making this determination without wavering, therefore it is called resolve.
Yuan means a female treasure.
Second, classifying them as belonging to the heterodox group.
This person then falls into the grasping of true non-truth, becoming an accomplice of the god Chikagai, confusing Buddha-bodhi, and losing the view of knowledge.
This is called the eighth cause of giving rise to deviant thoughts, establishing the result of rampant defilements.
Contradicting the perfect penetration, turning one's back on the city of nirvana, and giving birth to the species of Mara in the heavens.

Giving rise to delusions and indulging in desires is truly not realizing the truth, yet considering this to be able to realize the truth and give rise to function, therefore it is called grasping of true non-truth.
Chikagai has not been seen translated correctly. Since this can transform sensual objects and enjoy them, it is a type of god in the desire realm.

As for the causes of deviant thoughts, since one gives rise to these deviant thoughts in samÄdhi and is unable to discern them well, this gives rise to the affairs of dust and afflictions, and thus it is the same as the heavenly demons.
Nine, those of the fixed nature of Å›rÄvakas, in two parts:
First, discussing what they understand.

Moreover, good men who have exhausted the emptiness of all conditioned phenomena, have already extinguished arising and ceasing, but have not yet perfected the subtle and wondrous stillness.ğŸ”½Within the illumination of life, they discriminate between the coarse and subtle, and discern the true and false, with cause and effect reciprocating, only seeking response, turning their backs on the path of purity, namely, seeing suffering, cutting off the cause of suffering, realizing cessation, cultivating the path, and resting in cessation, no longer progressing. Those who give rise to conviction, the Älaya-consciousness is revealed, and thus it is called the illumination of life.

Since consciousness contains the seeds of both contaminated and uncontaminated dharmas, now within this they discriminate and discern that contaminated suffering and its cause are coarse and false, while the uncontaminated path and cessation are subtle and true.
Discarding the coarse and false suffering and accumulation, while retaining the refined and true path and cessation, is called discriminating the refined and coarse, etc.
Cultivating the path is the cause, realizing cessation is the response. Only taking this, it is called only seeking.
Turning away from the pure path originally cultivates the perfect contemplation, the equality of the dharma realm, free from the defilements of the two extremes, called the pure path.
Now giving rise to the understanding of disgust and joy of the Lesser Vehicle, it is called turning away.
So-called explains the previous meaning.
Second, judging it as belonging to the deviant group.

This person then falls into the fixed nature of the Å›rÄvakas, becoming companions with those of the Saá¹ƒgha who have not heard much and are arrogant, confusing the Buddha's enlightenment and losing the correct view.
This is called the ninth mind of perfect refined response, resulting in the fruition of quiescence.
Opposing the perfect penetration, turning away from the city of nirvÄá¹‡a, and being born in the seed of entangled emptiness.

As for fixed nature, for the time being, it is judged as fixed nature based on the one period of turning towards quiescence without change. In reality, there is a number of kalpas, and one will eventually return to the superior vehicle.
As for the monks who have not heard [the Dharma], they do not understand the aggregate of consciousness and mistake it for nirvÄá¹‡a, thus they are the same as this.
Round means all-encompassing, and pure means not coarse. Having already left the aggregate of formations, it is the source of all life, thus it is called round and pure.
In accordance with false conceptualization, it is called in accord with the mind.
Ten, those of fixed nature as pratyekabuddhas, two:
First, based on what they understand.
Moreover, good men who have exhausted the emptiness of all formations, have already extinguished birth and cessation, but have not yet perfected the subtle and wondrous stillness and cessation.

If, in the clear and pure enlightened awareness that is perfectly integrated, they give rise to a profound and wondrous investigation, and thus establish nirvÄá¹‡a without progressing further, and give rise to a decisive understanding, originally contemplating the perfectly integrated essence of enlightened awareness, now seeing the aggregate of consciousness separate from the birth and cessation of formations, considering it profound and wondrous, establishing it as nirvÄá¹‡a.
They do not know the continuous flow, thus they do not progress further.
Second, judging them to belong to the group of the heterodox.

This person will fall into the fixed nature of a pratyekabuddha, becoming a companion to those who are solitary and do not turn their minds, and will be confused about the Buddha's enlightenment and lose the correct view.
This is called the tenth kind of person who takes the pure and wondrous mind as the result of clear and still illumination.
They go against the perfect penetration, turn their backs on the city of nirvana, and give rise to the perfect and clear illumination without the wonderful function of transforming the perfect seeds.
Recognizing the aggregate of consciousness as perfect enlightenment corresponds to taking false imagination as the pure and wondrous mind.
Still and unmoving, not without clear understanding, therefore it is called clear and still.

Realizing the perfect and clear illumination of the enlightenment of consciousness, without the wonderful function of transforming with compassion, therefore it is called the perfect and clear illumination without the wonderful function of transforming the perfect seeds.

This is of this kind.
Third, concluding with an exhortation to spread and proclaim, there are four parts:
First, concluding the previous and pointing out the faults.
Ä€nanda!

These ten kinds of dhyÄna are halfway to becoming crazy. Relying on delusion, they give rise to the realization of satisfaction in what is insufficient. They all arise from the interaction of the mind and consciousness in the aggregate of consciousness.

Ignorant sentient beings do not consider their own abilities. When encountering this present [teaching], each uses their previously loved deluded mind to rest, taking it to be the ultimate place of return, and says they have attained unsurpassed enlightenment. Not examining the subtle arising and ceasing of the aggregate of consciousness, they take it to be realization, so it is said relying on delusion and so forth.
The rest of the text is understandable.
Second, the exhortation to propagate and proclaim.

You should preserve the mind and uphold the TathÄgata's Way. Transmit this Dharma door to future generations after my nirvÄá¹‡a, universally causing sentient beings to understand this meaning, not allowing them to see mÄras and create deep misfortune for themselves. Deeply encouraging future generations to understand the appearances of the ten realms arising when the aggregates have not yet been exhausted.
Knowing and being aware, the mÄras of views will naturally cease;
Deluded and grasping, one will certainly fall into bias and evil.
Entering the Buddha's knowledge and insight is the stage of realizing the truth.
From the beginning is the initial cultivation; accomplishment is the fulfillment of the fruition.
Not encountering detours means there will be no more winding paths in between.
It is the same as the previous ten categories.
Third, revealing what the Buddha rode.

This Dharma door was previously in the worlds of the past, during eons as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, where dust-like TathÄgatas rode this mind to open up and attain the unsurpassed Way.
There is not a single Buddha who does not destroy the five aggregates to attain enlightenment. They are all able to understand and therefore avoid detours.
Fourth, the function of exhausting the aggregates.

If the aggregate of consciousness is exhausted, then your present faculties will be mutually usable. From this mutual use, you will be able to enter the vajra-like enlightened mind of the bodhisattvas.
The mutual use of the present faculties refers to the realization of the acceptance of non-arising in the third stage of practice mentioned above. This has already been seen in the previous text.
Entering the enlightened mind from mutual use means that this mutual use itself is already entering the stage of enlightened mind, because mutual use is the state of mastery.

As the previous text says, When the reversal of the flow is complete, the six functions do not operate. Up to all the secret, perfect, pure, and wondrous qualities of the TathÄgatas manifest within it. This person will then attain the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.

From here, gradually cultivating according to one's practice, establishing the holy stages, this is called the third stage of gradual practice. This begins from the stage of dry wisdom and ends at the stage of equal enlightenment, all not apart from this third stage of gradual practice to establish it.
Now, in terms of entering the specific from the general, it is said to enter from the state of mutual use.
As for vajra, it is because this practitioner from beginning to end all by cultivating and practicing the vajra samÄdhi attains accomplishment.

Therefore, the previous text says, These various stages all use the vajra to contemplate the ten profound metaphors of illusion, using the vipaÅ›yanÄ of the tathÄgatas in Å›amatha to purify and realize, gradually entering deeply.

Or this may be about those with sharp faculties who reach the stage of dry wisdom, arouse spiritual transformation, and thus transcend the causal stage and directly enter wondrous enlightenment, thus separately receiving the title of vajra.

If one is of dull faculties, following the practices one engages in, one goes through the various stages again, and thus cannot be said to have attained the vajra stage, but is only called dry wisdom.

If this stage is established after the final mind of equal enlightenment, then how is it that the text previously states, The TathÄgata flows in the reverse direction, and the bodhisattva flows in the forward direction until they meet at the edge of enlightenment, which is called equal enlightenment?
How can it be that at the point of meeting they further establish the stage of dry wisdom?

The ancients were confused about this and further established the stage of vajra dry wisdom after equal enlightenment. This truly misled later students, as it is neither reasonable nor supported by the texts. I dare not accept it.

The perfectly bright mind of essence gives rise to transformation within, like a pure lapis lazuli containing a precious moon. In this way, one transcends the ten faiths, ten abodes, ten practices, ten dedications, four preparatory states of mind, the vajra stages practiced by bodhisattvas, and equal enlightenment and perfect brightness, and enters the ocean of the TathÄgata's wondrous adornments, perfecting enlightenment and returning to the unobtainable.

Having already realized the perfect subtlety in the mind of dry wisdom, this mind-nature suddenly gives rise to all practices and suddenly possesses all virtues, therefore it is said to give rise to transformation.

The mind of wisdom is like lapis lazuli, the causal practices are like jewels, and the fruition virtues are like the moon. This metaphor shows that the infinite is manifested within the one, and the one is manifested within the infinite. The causal practices and fruition virtues are simultaneously complete, unobstructed and perfectly clear, therefore it is like a lapis lazuli containing a jewel moon within.
Surpassing the causes to enter the fruition means that because the causes and effects are complete due to the previous giving rise to transformation, one is then able to surpass.

Because of the sufficiency of blessings, it is called the ocean of adornments. Because of the sufficiency of wisdom, it is perfect enlightenment. Because the principle is ultimate, it returns to the unobtainable, which is the great nirvÄá¹‡a, eternally quiescent and unobtainable. This is for those of the lowest capacity in the perfect and sudden teaching who are also sharp.
Because of being of the lowest grade, one attains entry into the stage only after the aggregate of consciousness is exhausted.
Because of being sharp, one gives rise to transformation here and surpasses all stages.
Question:
Previously, when the aggregate of perception was exhausted, it was said that one ascended through the sixty holy stages of the bodhisattvas.
Now, when the aggregate of consciousness is exhausted, why is it said that one transcends?
The answer is:
Previously, it was explained for those of slightly dull faculties among the superior ones, and by analogy, there should also be those who suddenly transcend.
Now, it is explained for those of sharp faculties among the inferior ones, and therefore it can be said that they transcend.
By analogy with the previous destruction of perception, there should also be those who ascend through the holy stages. It is just that the superior and inferior are alternately presented.
The exhaustion of the aggregates of conception and formation should be the place where those of middling faculties transcend and ascend, but it is omitted.

First, generally pointing out demonic matters.
This is the subtle demonic matter analyzed by the illuminating wisdom of vipaÅ›yanÄ within the Å›amatha of the past buddhas.
Illuminating wisdom refers to the wisdom of contemplation.

When the demonic realm appears before you, if you are able to understand it clearly, wash away the defilements of the mind, and not fall into wrong views,
